conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the small block and the plank to determine the condition for F1.
Identify the forces acting on the small block: weight (mg), normal force (N), frictional force (f = mu N), vertical force (F2), horizontal force (F1).
Vertical forces must be in equilibrium: F2 = mg + mu N.
Horizontal force F1 is resisted by the frictional force: F1 = mu N.
Relate normal force N to vertical force F2: F2 = mg + mu N, substitute into horizontal force equation: F1 = mu (F2 - mg).
Solve for F1: F1 = mu (mg + mu N - mg), simplify to F1 = mu^2 N, since mu = 0.20, F1 = 0.20 N.
Calculate normal force N using vertical force equation: N = (F2 - mg) / mu, substitute into equation for F1: F1 = 0.20 * (F2 - mg) / 0.20.
Determine condition for F1: F1 = F2 - 0.80 * 10, F1 = F2 - 8.00, F2 must be greater than 8.00 N, so F1 > 0.
For plank to move upward, F1 must be greater than zero: F1 > F2 - 8.00, since F2 > 8.00, F1 > 0.
